ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned various new reactions and mechanisms in organometallic chemistry which allowed me to understand reactions that I have seen prior to this course.
A lot! Especially about the fundamental importance of determine metal identity, d electron counting, etc when thinking about reactions and catalytic cycles.
The basics of organometallic chemistry and a basic understanding of mechanistic tests that can be used in transition metal catalyzed reations.
I leaned a lot of core concepts about inorganic chem.
This course provides an opportunity for me to review the fundamental concepts in organometallic chemistry and practice applying them in understanding research-relevant scenarios.
I developed my first sense of organometallics, as i hadnt had any courses on metals before.

I developed a strong understanding of electron counting, metal carbonyls, and other common organometallic compounds. Given the fundamental approach of the class, it further strengthened my understanding of orbitals, DFT, and electronic effects in metal complexes.
I was able to build on the lessons of the previous course to further explore organometallic complexes and their interactions with functional groups to form new species.
Organometallic reactions, different types of transition metal complexes, applications
Fundamental organometallic principles and reactions along with a bit of applications
This course builds well on the introduction to organometallic compounds and synthesis that I received in CHEM 252.
I learned about the fundamental concepts of organometallic chemistry.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed going up to the board every lecture to work on practice problems in a group. Sometimes it felt that we were switching topics abruptly but overall the flow made sense. I think with time the organization of the course will improve.
I really liked the group questions at the board, and think those could have been done more frequently or for longer periods of time.
Wide breadth of topics. Sometimes switching between the chalkboard and the powerpoint slides got a little confusing/difficult to review later.
I liked the professor engagement. I thought the notes could be presented a little better. I was confused at times.

Strengths:

There are many opportunities for practice--including problem sets, presentations, and workshops during class periods.

Weaknesses:

The instruction can be more organized. It appears to me that some materials were presented over and over again at different points of the semester.

The lectures were kind of disorganized. It was difficult to follow the thread of each class period and what we were supposed to be focused on and connecting back to. But the material was interesting and Pat was engaging.
Some classes felt more like lectures with 20+ examples written on the board for us to write down. Otherwise, the classes were engaging and emphasized the why and not just the what.
One of the strengths of this class was the inclusion of some in-class exercises, as they really helped to reinforce the points of the day's lecture.

Strengths: Overall, I would recommend this course for undergrads. The pset workload was pretty manageable; the literature presentation exercise is engaging and a good way to learn more about an organometallic topic too. The in-class exercises, though very difficult, were helpful to provide a break in the lecturing and practice what we learned. Pat Holland is a very nice and understanding prof; he'll give help if you ask.
Weaknesses: The lectures were sometimes hard to follow. Only a few lectures had slides on Canvas, and the few slides published made little sense outside of the lecture context. I felt there could've been much more organization in the class structure to better learn. I got most stuff from the textbooks, not class notes.

I enjoyed the problem sets and class participation workshops. I also appreciatr the take home final. The lectures were a bit disjointed though and I feel as if some of the more challenging problems were not addressed properly

This course is among the better taught in the department, and the group classwork in each session helped reinforce the most important concepts. I found the problem sets and exams particularly helpful. The paper presentations were the weakest part of the class in terms of learning materialeach group had too little time to explain its paper in depth, and I didn't retain much at all from the presentations.

I greatly appreciated how knowledge was presented as cumulative in this course, and how the problem sheet questions allowed us to consolidate the material learned in class. I also enjoyed the references to very recent scientific literature.

Strengths- I liked the final project, and Professor Holland is a great instructor (really cares about his students + consistently clear explanations).
Weaknesses- I was confused at times about the "plot" of the course. I wasn't sure how the different lectures would connect, and it seems as though the topics were kind of random (or I didn't understand their rationale).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yep! So long as they are interesting in inorganic or organic chemistry.
Yes, great for an organic student who wants to have more tools for understanding/working on metal chemistry.
Yes, I thought it was essential to learning the core concepts of inorganic chem.
I would not, because the course material is not very organized, and this may necessitate students to do a lot of self-study outside of class.
Yes, because its pretty fundamental to what one needs to understand organic reactions and catalysis
Yes. This is a great class for students looking to better understanding metals and organometallic complexes.
I would only recommend to those in the Chem Major, as it is a grad-level course.
Yes, though a bit disorganized, Pat Holland is a very good professor and the class is very reasonable and fair.
I would recommend this course as an advanced elective for any student interested in inorganic or organometallic chemistry.

Yes! I think this course is a great introduction to organometallic chemistry and can greatly help students from any chemistry field understand the current scientific literature in inorganic chemistry.
